description: AWS Well Architected Hybrid Networking Bestpractices
name: Hybrid Networking Lens

helpfulResource.displayText: Amazon VPC IP Address Manager (IPAM) is a VPC feature that makes it easier for you to plan, track, and monitor IP addresses for your AWS workloads. When using Amazon VPC IPAM in conjuction with AWS Organizations you can monitor IP address usage throughout your AWS Organization and share IP address pools across member accounts.

improvementPlan.displayText: To get insights into the usage of your IP Addresses in AWS, AWS recommends to implement AWS VPC IPAM. AWS IPAM enabled across AWS accounts and provide you with a holistc view of your IP Address consumption on AWS

choices.title: Are you using any IPAM solutions for AWS

helpfulResource.displayText: As AWS adoption increases throughout an organization, the number of networks and virtual private clouds (VPCs) to support them also increases. Customers can see growth upwards of tens, hundreds, or in the case of the enterprise, thousands of VPCs. Architecting for scale is thefore a key aspect for a sucessfull AWS implementation

improvementPlan.displayText: Keep scale in mind when designing VPC's in AWS. VPC CDIR ranges can be extended but not reduced. If needed an AWS VPC can have two different CIDR's associated to it. Such design can help with IP exhaustion.

choices.title: Are you simplifying routing, connectivity and isolation boundries

questions.description: When creating a hybrid network between AWS and on premises you will have to think about what CIDR ranges you would like to allocate to your AWS VPC's, what AWS Networking Serivces you want use to connect to the AWS VPC's from on-onpremises, as well as how you will advertise your routes between the on-premises and AWS networks. To help with the management of IP Address spaces as well as the management of routes, customers implement various mechanims to simplify such network connectivity.
questions.title: How do you ensure efficient IP address allocation across your VPCs and on-premises networks?
